front.div:
Abstract The electrochemically initiated reaction of p-phenylenediamines with sulfide in aqueous media is well documented.
We now report the adaptation of this chemistry into nonaqueous media. This is critically appraised as a means of
detecting sulfide. The electrochemically initiated reaction of N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine with sulfide is shown at
both macro-and platinum microdisk electrodes with quantitative detection of sulfide produced by means of the
enhanced currents observed upon its addition. The linear detection range for sulfide is dependent on the
concentration of N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine present with a linear range from 28 Â± 3290 mM and a limit of
detection of 22 mM achievable. This represents a large increase compared to that found previously in aqueous media
and offers the prospect of more ready applications in high temperature systems.
